title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Madhu Pandit Dasa |  SB 1.7.30 | 31-01-2016
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Now, based on the advice of Lord Krishna, Arjuna also decided to counteract the Brahmastra sent by Ashwathana by himself releasing a counteracting Brahmastra.
segments.summary: Arjuna, following Krishna's advice, prepares to counter Ashwathama's Brahmastra with his own.

segments.key_quote: Brahmastra is similar to the nuclear weapon of modern days.
segments.summary: The speaker draws a parallel between the Brahmastra and modern nuclear weapons, explaining the concept of converting matter into energy.

segments.key_quote: Whatever the Shastra says, it is a great science, science is included, this modern science is included in the Bhagavata.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how modern science, particularly Einstein's equation, validates the concept of the Brahmastra and suggests that the Srimad Bhagavatam contains advanced scientific knowledge.

segments.key_quote: Just like Brahmastra released material energy, we discussed Brahmastra released material energy by chanting certain mantras, we discussed how spiritual energy can be released by chanting the Hare Krishna Mahamantra.
segments.summary: The lecture transitions from material energy (Brahmastra) to spiritual energy, explaining that the Hare Krishna Mahamantra can release spiritual energy characterized by Sat, Chit, and Ananda.

segments.key_quote: If we hear the Mahamantra attentively without any distraction, mantra after mantra if you hear that, then our Atma will touch our soul, our real existence will touch the absolute existence Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of attentive chanting (Japa) of the Hare Krishna Mahamantra to connect the soul with Krishna and liberate it from the illusion of material existence.

segments.key_quote: By touching the Hare Krishna Mahamantra, by touching the sound Hare Krishna Mahamantra, when there is flow of Sat energy by the mercy of the Lord, then one existence would lighten up its eternal existence beyond this body.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how connecting with the Hare Krishna Mahamantra allows the flow of Sat energy, illuminating one's eternal existence, and how distractions of the mind hinder this process during Japa.

segments.key_quote: Your Japa is just automatic, you are chanting round after round and then your Japa is finishing but your thinking has not finished.
segments.summary: The speaker describes how inattentive chanting leads to mechanical repetition without genuine connection, emphasizing the need for continuous attention during Japa to avoid disconnection.

segments.key_quote: You should make a sankalpa to keep the iron in the fire for quite some time, at least one Mala you take, nothing I shall do now from beginning to end of this Mala, I shall continue to do this only nothing else.
segments.summary: The speaker advises making a firm resolve (sankalpa) to maintain continuous attention during at least one round of Japa, avoiding any distractions to prevent disconnection from the sound (Shabda).

segments.key_quote: Similarly the mind should follow the activity of chanting and hearing and by doing that automatically you are hearing, automatically you are hearing your attention is following the activity of your attention is on the hearing.
segments.summary: The speaker suggests engaging the mind by actively following the activity of chanting and hearing, similar to following a ball in table tennis, to maintain focus during Japa.

segments.key_quote: If you are standing in the railway station, railway platform and one train is going across and if I tell you just count the number of bogies that will go by, then your attention will be one, two, three...
segments.summary: Using the analogy of counting train bogies, the speaker illustrates how focusing attention on a specific task keeps the mind engaged, and reiterates the importance of continuous attention during chanting, comparing it to keeping iron in the fire to heat it thoroughly.

segments.key_quote: At least train yourself that one mala is I will have a sankalpa that from beginning till end of this mala I have a sankalpa I will not do anything with my mind but only follow the Hare Krishna mantra.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of making a strong resolve (sankalpa) to focus solely on the Hare Krishna mantra during Japa, defining Japa as a meditation on doing rather than seeing.

segments.key_quote: Japa is doing meditation. That means don't do anything else. Stay only this, chanting, hearing, chanting, hearing, chanting, hearing.
segments.summary: The speaker differentiates between meditation on seeing and meditation on doing, explaining that Japa is the latter, requiring focused engagement in chanting and hearing, and that the mala aids in giving the mind a connected task.

segments.key_quote: Between the two beats, the sankalpa shakti should be there to go, to go forward. Should not. There has, your soul has to be.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the importance of maintaining a strong resolve (sankalpa) and determination to stay focused on the sound of the Hare Krishna mantra during Japa, preventing the mind from wandering and ensuring a connection with the divine.
